body: @tqchen @yzhliu @srkreddy1238  Now we only have one graph_runtime interface for both C++ and Python. Currently we can pass either 4 or 5 arguments to graph_runtime.create in the C++ backend to keep support for Java and js because heterogeneous execution for them has not implemented yet.  This is also documented in the code.
I think this is now in a state where we should merge and address any other issues in follow-up PRs.

Thanks, @yzhliu @jroesch @alex-weaver @zhiics @junrushao1994 @masahi @joshpoll @weberlo @grwlf @MarisaKirisame for reviews.

I merge this PR given that it reaches a state of test passing and most comments addressed. Let us get the balls rolling with follow up PRs
I plan on opening two PRs one for the evaluation and one for the documentation and reference manual.

@yzhliu , @tqchen can you merge this ?
I have following PR on top of this.
Thanks @masahi @srkreddy1238 this is now merged

@srkreddy1238 I did some further quick reviews. If nobody is going to review this PR, I am going to do another round of reviews over the weekend and do some further learning on golang. Please also send in a docker recipe so that we can hook things up do the CI
ye, I always feel confused about this too
Just to confirm this, is there anything special about NHWC support? Did you try to convert it on the fly to NCHW ?
please request reviews from the reviewers
related PR for CUDA https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/pull/1735
@anijain2305 please follow up to fix the recent reviews comments and let us bring this in
Hmm, maybe we should add a detailed document page about the differences
some followup discussion here as well https://discuss.tvm.ai/t/how-to-use-tensorize/424/6

#1718 does on the fly conversion of NHWC to NCHW  (convolution and pool) to compile for cuda target.

This PR is to support native NCHW models (like resnet which is NCHW across the layers.)

@tqchen 
Do we make a new docker image for go environment?
Or 
Simplify by ```golang-go, golint, golang-doc``` packages to CPU docker and make a script for golang test case execution .
cc @masahi @siju-samuel @yzhliu welcome to review.
I see, ideally, we want to let the front end just to simple translation and apply followup passes in the IR to transform the layout when necessary
We can merge that into the cpu docker for now

One question is whether passing a constant argument is supported now. If not, can we pass expr, like FloatImm?
We should check the strong uniqueness, I think it makes sense to have one function that checks all the things

I agree with @tqchen I think strong uniqueness makes since, in debug mode we can check this more frequently to aid in development and bugs. As the pass infrastructure evolves it would make sense to add a sanity mode, which does the checks aggressively to suss out bugs.
I left some first pass review, could you also add tests of various scenarios? We could use C++ tests or expose and test in Python? @tqchen what do you think?

I also lean favor of strong uniqueness mode. It also free us from using RAII (which is uglier then just a function invocation)
Do you two want me to write a copy function, which, given an expr, generate a structurally equivalent expression with new var? It will come handy in optimization.
I don't think we need a copy function yet unless I'm missing something.
Yes, we dont need it yet. I will open a separate pr for it.

Thanks for all the changes. The only complain I have is that the intrinsic functions' parameter naming seems to be confusing and it is hard for me to tell what it does exactly, we should be cautious on how we name the API since they are going to be used by the users. Maybe one way to make things clear is to document the behavior of the intrinsic using array and pseudo code.

 Everyone is also welcomed to put weight on the API @ajtulloch @vinx13 @yizhi
In the interest of making development faster, we can focus on getting most test cases in python and have minimum c++ test cases that covers data structure correctness

@zhiics some final followup comments. @jackwish @srkreddy1238 @yzhliu @tmoreau89 please take a round of review and https://docs.tvm.ai/contribute/code_review.html#approve-and-request-changes-explicitly

@zhreshold, sorry about the late reply. There is add add layer after every conv layer in the legacy squeezenet onnx model, which is transformed to expand_dims + broadcast_add after being converted to nnvm graph (see debug_str printout here: https://gist.github.com/hlu1/282e304a064a4315b69223492d672f27). There is also no softmax layer in the end, so making the legacy onnx model work won't be relevant to this PR. The current squeezenet model in the onnx model zoo has the same network layers as in https://github.com/DeepScale/SqueezeNet/blob/master/SqueezeNet_v1.1/deploy.prototxt, which has a softmax layer as the last layer and no add layer in the middle.
this is closed for now, we have decided to keep python2 compact for the new core relay IR
Thanks to @zhiics #1695 is getting close state to merging

Isn't this only useful if you want to create an exactly duplicate of the expression? For example if we write a transform pass its fine to re-bind a variable as long as its bound uniquely each time. It doesn't make sense to do renaming in that case.
@joshpoll @weberlo @MarisaKirisame @slyubomirsky could you guys take passes over the content. I am going to fix/clean up things which changed between last week and the final PR.
@junrushao1994 @zhiics @yzhliu @ZihengJiang please review

I think this go with the transform pass - instead of rebinding the variable everytime we transform through the var, with this we can call Copy instead.
Also in inlining we need copy since we are duplicating.

Maybe we can wait until we have some concrete need of the deep copy transformation pass to introduce the rebinding of vars. 

We also need to keep in mind that many of the things are already CSEed as they get constructed, and somehow we would like to keep that property.
Also the name Copy is a bit confusing, although it does copy but the primary thing is to regenerate the bindings.
We might need a good RFC on the text format and how it exchanges with the current IR
should I close or just leave it as is?
@jroesch please https://docs.tvm.ai/contribute/code_review.html#approve-and-request-changes-explicitly

@tqchen Thanks for helping out with clear documentation. I have thought more clearly about the API and realized that it doesn't need any parameters as the tensor intrin is specific for Skylake machine. I have added a small summary with a pseudo code. Please review again and let me know if it needs more improvement.
If we don't plan to act on this for a while, maybe we could close it and reopen when we think it is close to a state to merge
cc @dmlc/tvm-team everyone is welcomed to comment on this as it will affect the API everyone is going to use
@kazum @merrymercy Could you please look into this PR? Am I understand it correctly that we are in the process of rewriting topi from Python to C++ with thin Python API?

very close proposals and difficult to decide on

Assuming the flow from GraphCompile would end up with schedules (and then LoweredFunc) on multiple devices followed by segregate into device specific lists. Finally these lists can be given to Proposal 1 or 2 for a single shot build.

Also nnvm can stick to combined ```tvm::runtime::Module``` instead of getting knowledge on host and device modules ..etc.

I vote for Proposal 2 and open to hear and accept community voice :)

In the context of TVMContext passed to graph runtime and with heterogeneous we are now passing a vector of TVMContext.

As I understand TVMContext is tightly coupled with compiled function.

Ref #1695 
- The vector of TVMContext is used for checking storage device type in the given TVMContext list or not.
- There would be only one version of tvm_op in the module (host or device) for each operation.

Hence I don't see why we need to pass TVMContext to graph runtime if storage already mapped to device_id. 

Am I missing any thing here ?

Or 

Is this vector of TVMContext is a backup plan to support a future version of Heterogeneous execution where 
- Compiled module holds multiple version of tvm_op for each target device.
- Dynamically user can pass TVMContext list to prioritize the device.
@merrymercy @masahi  @srkreddy1238 @tqchen Could you please do the initial round of review. Thanks in advance.

I think proposal 3 also works well, we can probably do it like this (I've personally experimented). In stead of manually combining modules, we can modify nnvm.compiler.build from `_build(funcs, target, target_host)` to:

1. _build([lower_func_list1, lower_func_list2], targets, host_target)` or dict device_module : lo
wered_funcs pairs.

2. `_build(funcs, func_cnts, targets, host_target)` where `funcs` are grouped in graph_compile.cc, i.e. [gpu, gpu, gpu, cpu, cpu, cpu, fpga, fpga], and 'func_cnts' is the number of lowered_funcs for each target. This is a little tricky, but I think it's okay. 

We can then call tvm.build several times to generate code and combined them together, e.g. having a simple combine_module API in build_module which calls `import`. The change of code seems not much because we anyway need to have lowered_func_list first for each device.

The context is passed to map the virtual device index(which is already in the plan) to the specific context. This can still be useful say we compiled a GPU module and we can map it to gpu(0) or gpu(1) during runtime
@zhiics please address the review comments

Thanks for the set of changes. Maybe we could put a bit more thought in terms of the intrinsic naming.  I think there are two sensible ways to do so:

- Use the native name for the intrinsic, e.g. dp4a
- Use the mathematical meaning of the intrinsic
   - Most intrinsic are doing matrix-vector product or dot product
      - We could use things like dot_8x1x8_int8_int8_int32

Thoughts?

I like the second option better as it is more accurate. 
For naming, how about we put the vector length and data type together. e.g. dot_4xint8_16x4xint8_16xint32. (this is AVX512, so there are 16 vector lanes)

Ideally, we should keep the old function parse as it is. And support a``` __call__ ``` of the hybrid script that calls parse and then generate an ExternOp.

````Python
import tvm
@tvm.hybrid.script
def outer_product(a, b):
    c = tvm.output((128, 128), dtype)
    for j in range(128):
        for i in range(128):
            c[i,j] = a[i] * b[j]
    return c

a = tvm.placeholder((128, ), 'float32', 'a')
b = tvm.placeholder((128, ), 'float32', 'b')
# returns an ExternOp
c = outer_product(a, b) 
d = tvm.compute(c.shape, lambda *i: c(*i)+1)
sch = tvm.create_schedule(d.op)
...
````
I did a quick round of reviews
OK. Then I know how an op works.
@tqchen but if we explicitly define the outputs, how can we do multi-output op, and how can we support in-place algorithms?

## Multi output case
```python
import tvm
@tvm.hybrid.script
def outer_product(a, b):
    c = tvm.output((128, 128), dtype)
    d = tvm.output((128, 128), dtype)

    for j in range(128):
        for i in range(128):
            c[i,j] = a[i] * b[j]
            d[i,j] = a[i] + 1
    return c, d

a = tvm.placeholder((128, ), 'float32', 'a')
b = tvm.placeholder((128, ), 'float32', 'b')
# returns an ExternOp
c0, c1 = outer_product(a, b) 
d = tvm.compute(c.shape, lambda *i: c0(*i)+c1(*i))
sch = tvm.create_schedule(d.op)
.
```

## Inplace Update
I agree that is harder to express an inplace update. The general design goal of the operator relation is that everything is immutable and there is no inplace update. We can still assign c and a to be the same buffer to achieve the effect of of inplace update though.

The main reason I think the above approach is nice is that the code itself is pretty consistent with tvm.compute flow and can be mixed together with other expressions. The only drawback of inplace update can be resolved by supporting inplace update hybrid code but do not support these for extern op for now

I like the old one better for 2 reasons:
1. Calling a hybrid script becomes more like calling a TVM built module, which makes code clean when doing sw-emulation verification
2. In-place algorithm support will be rollback, if we use the new style
Why don't we do this?
``` Python
import tvm
@tvm.hybrid.script
def outer_product(a, b, c):
    for j in range(128):
        for i in range(128):
            c[i,j] = a[i] * b[j]

a = tvm.placeholder((128, ), 'float32', 'a')
b = tvm.placeholder((128, ), 'float32', 'b')
c = tvm.placeholder((128, ), 'float32', 'b')
# returns c's op
# if it is multi-output, return the tuple of output ops
op = outer_product(a, b, c)
d = tvm.compute(c.shape, lambda *i: c(*i)+1)
sch = tvm.create_schedule(d.op)
```
In general, it is an extension of the current hybrid module.

@ehsanmok @jroesch @nhynes it is a good time to revive this thread, let us add follow up comments and work to merge this in

I take another look at the PR. My high level complain is still that we need to minimize gotvm.h and gotvm.cc. So that we can directly call into functions like TVMModGetFunction, and do the free of the created CString on the Go side.

It is always confusing that certain things have to be handled by the caller. I can understand that there might be need for introducing a union type, but still in that case, it is likely that we could simply reinterpret a piece of aligned memory as the union object itself(c.f. https://golang.org/cmd/cgo/ C's union type are represented by byte array with same length) (you can likely do memcpy of data content into it.

Minimizing gotvm.h interface is definitely possible as most of the places wrapper is a direct call.

Reason, I wrapped still is to keep them in one place which helps to add call flow debugging if required later.

Please confirm on this to minimise the wrapper as much as possible.

I think it is good to have a clear distinguishment between the TVM C FFI and the necessary wrapper. Minimizing these code will likely makes maintenance easier, if we need some debugging, we can still do so in the tvm runtime

As @masahi said, you are probably having issues with the shared library you built(`libtvm.so`), the error is missing symbol:
````bash
  c++filt _ZTIN3tvm4NodeE
typeinfo for tvm::Node
```` 
Typical cause of this error is missing implementation for virtual functions. Actually in the old nnvm repo, someone had the [exact same issue](https://webcache.googleusercontent.com/search?q=cache:qih-a3vlSzAJ:https://github.com/dmlc/nnvm/issues/332+&cd=1&hl=en&ct=clnk&gl=us&client=ubuntu) with dynamic library.

It would help if you can share how you build tvm step by step. And given your stack trace, i guess the following code snippet is sufficient to reproduce your error:
````bash
# cd to tvm repo root
PROJ=`pwd`
export PYTHONPATH=$PROJ/python:$PROJ/nnvm/python:$PROJ/topi/python
python3
# then inside the repl, try to import tvm
import tvm
````

Currently, we cannot run a `conv2d+bn` model directly because of error with int8 bn weights.
In `sym.batch_norm(data=int8_conv)`, error occurs when it tries to compute sqrt of int in `fuse___add_scalar___sqrt___rdiv_scalar___elemwise_mul` because bn params are int8.
Some hack may be needed to compute bn params in fp32.
@tqchen Could you help?
need to fix the conflict
Thanks everyone's effort!

@tqchen the last number of changes addressed some of my concerns and comments above. Besides improving docs and some other smaller things (like `#[inline]` attributes) that can be done later, my main concern is related to [#1226](https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/issues/1226) and seems allowing it in the [build](https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/pull/1597/files#diff-6228dfbca0bfcb4a4662ce8cc1ccf963R8). If @nhynes thinks it was already resolved, then I think there shouldn't be a major blocking issue to merge. If not, then at least we can remove the feature and fix it later!

> my main concern is related to #1226 and seems allowing it in the build

I haven't looped around to fixing that, but since the rust runtime is mostly useful for Wasm (single threaded) and SGX (which doesn't manage its own threads), it's not a blocker.

I will take this up. I had some preliminary implementation using proposal 3. It looks that proposal 2 is more user-friendly. Let me change to it.

I think there would be more discussions about how we should pass multiple targets to GraphCompile and how a node should take the device information, etc. I will update here when the PR is out.
@nhynes Ok! So we shouldn't allow the related `par-launch-alloc` feature in master until it is resolved.
Facebook's glow (https://github.com/pytorch/glow) has a clang-format, as well as clang-tidy, maybe we could learn something from them.
PR: https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/pull/1774
Please add the regression test to test_lang_tensorize.py

@zhiics 

Ref. RFC #1242 
- It talks about ```FComputeFallback``` which indicates the operator to have a fallback to CPU.

Here the device_types is selected based on the result of ```FComputeFallBack``` not by explicit arguments to nnvm build. We could continue to have targets passed to nnvm build to control the fall back devices.
Am I missing anything here ?

How about another PR first to demonstrate the fallback behavior of operator and copy insertion before integrating nnvm build to tvm build.
Thanks @slyubomirsky this is now merged
Actually, I just fixed the bug. Turns out the issue was that the temporal workspaces only work correctly if they have the same alignment as the dtype they're supposed to hold. Go figure.
